question: Two cells of emfs $E_{1}$ and $E_{2}$ and internal resistances $r_{1}$ and $r_{2}$ $(E_{2}>E_{1}$ and $r_{2}>r_{1})$ respectively, are connected in parallel as shown in figure. The equivalent emf of the combination is $E_{eq}$. Then
images/f2a3b4c5-d6e7-4f8a-9b0c-1d2e3f4a5b6c.png
explanation: The equivalent EMF for parallel combination is weighted by inverse resistance: $E_{eq} = \frac{E_1/r_1 + E_2/r_2}{1/r_1 + 1/r_2}$.
The value of $E_{eq}$ always lies between $E_1$ and $E_2$.
Since $r_1 < r_2$, the cell with lower internal resistance ($E_1$) dominates the equivalent value, so $E_{eq}$ is closer to $E_1$.
